title: CRB-65 Score for Pneumonia Severity
description: Stratifies severity of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) to determine outpatient versus inpatient treatment using 4 clinical criteria (without blood urea nitrogen)

parameters.name: confusion
parameters.description: New onset confusion or altered mental status

ranges.interpretation: Consider hospital evaluation or short inpatient observation. 30-day mortality risk 1-10%.
Hospital admission recommended. Consider ICU assessment. 30-day mortality risk >10%.

references: Lim WS, van der Eerden MM, Laing R, Boersma WG, Karalus N, Town GI, et al. Defining community acquired pneumonia severity on presentation to hospital: an international derivation and validation study. Thorax. 2003;58(5):377-382. doi:10.1136/thorax.58.5.377
Capelastegui A, España PP, Quintana JM, Areitio I, Gorordo I, Egurrola M, et al. Validation of a predictive rule for the management of community-acquired pneumonia. Eur Respir J. 2006;27(1):151-157.

McNally M, Curtain J, O'Brien KK, Dimitrov BD, Fahey T. Validity of British Thoracic Society guidance (the CRB-65 rule) for predicting the severity of pneumonia in general practice: systematic review and meta-analysis. Br J Gen Pract. 2010;60(579):e423-433.
formula: Sum of: Confusion (1 point) + Respiratory rate ≥30 (1 point) + Blood pressure <90/<60 mmHg (1 point) + Age ≥65 years (1 point)
notes: CRB-65 is a simplified version of CURB-65 that does not require blood urea nitrogen measurement
Particularly useful in primary care settings where laboratory tests may not be readily available
Validated in multiple countries for community-acquired pneumonia severity assessment
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and local guidelines
Not validated for healthcare-associated or hospital-acquired pneumonia
Confusion defined as new onset altered mental status or disorientation
Blood pressure criteria: systolic <90 mmHg OR diastolic ≤60 mmHg
Age ≥65 years includes all patients 65 years of age and older
Consider patient comorbidities and social circumstances in treatment decisions
